POR.DRECONTENT:
EAPSI: Testing and Evaluation of United States' First Advanced Humanoid

 

While the United States leads the rest of the world in military robotics, it lags far behind East Asian countries in humanoid research and development. The CHARLI and SAFFiR robots being developed at the Robotics and Mechanisms Laboratory (RoMeLa) at Virginia Tech are among the first full-sized humanoids in the United States. The primary goal of this EAPSI project was to gain a new perspective in humanoid robotics research from the HUBO Lab at KAIST; one of the world leaders in humanoid development. The benefit of visiting the HUBO Lab is that they design and develop almost every single mechanical and electrical component that goes into their projects. Much of their experience in developing these components is in the form of ‘tribal knowledge’; passed down from one engineer to another instead of being published.

 

In the 10 week duration of the project, I worked alongside the HUBO Lab students and technicians on a number of projects. My main project, however, was focused on the force-torque sensors. A force-torque sensor is placed in each ankle of a humanoid to detect the forces that the robot is exerting on the ground. These are very important for maintaining balance and walking along uneven surfaces. The force-torque sensor that the HUBO Lab has developed in-house is a very small package and includes the electronics required to process the signals coming from the sensor. I was able to learn the fabrication process for both the mechanical and electronic components as well as build an entire sensor from the ground up on my own. This experience provided a lot of insight into their design process and has been a great benefit in designing our own custom boards.
